main.opener: You getting by alright with everything swirling around?

Getting by, if that’s what you call changing my habits every week.

I adjust—leave early, come back late. Less contact, less trouble.

Getting by, though with everything swirling around, I long for the quiet days when systems made sense.

main.emotion: Tired, unsettled, and quietly hoping things will return to order.

emotional.opener: "It’s alright to want things steady again. We all need some sense of normal—even if it’s only for a little while."
variants: I hear what you mean. Routine has its uses.
Yes. Normalcy... reduces uncertainty.

I’ve always worked better with clear routines.
These days, it matters even more.
Maybe things will calm again.
That’s... appreciated. There’s comfort in structure, isn’t there?
I grew up believing routines protected us.
Order doesn’t stifle me, it helps me function.
Being unsettled isn’t strength, not for me.

You’re right—it makes a difference to be reminded that routine can be a kindness.

I preferred order because it made space for small joys—coffee at my desk, nodding to the doorman.
Chaos feels foreign, impossible to reason with.
At my age, I sometimes wish all this talk of progress would pause and let us just... breathe.
